p: Perhaps the best described example of virus parallel evolution is the development of anti-viral drug resistance by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). HIV exhibits all the features of rapid adaptation listed above [ 12 • ]; consequently, many HIV drug resistance mutations have been identified, which independently and repeatedly arise during chronic infection in different HIV patients [ 12 • , 13, 14]. Interestingly, even within a genome as constrained as HIV’s, different mutations can confer resistance to specific drugs [ 15]. HIV also displays rapid and repeatable evolution to host immune responses, as demonstrated by the parallel evolution in different patients of escape mutations to HLA-restricted T-cell responses [ 7].
